hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of a binary tree and how to traverse it. Each node has a value, and you will need to access these values level by level.
Consider using a breadth-first search (BFS) approach. BFS is ideal for level-order traversal, which will help you gather nodes level by level.
As you traverse each level, keep track of the maximum value found in that level. You can initialize a variable to store the maximum value for each level.
Think about how you will store the maximum values for each level. A list or array could work well for this purpose, where each index corresponds to a tree level.
Remember to handle the case where the binary tree might be empty. What should your function return if there are no nodes in the tree?
When implementing BFS, you can use a queue to keep track of nodes to visit. Each time you process a node, enqueue its children for the next level.
As you process each node, compare its value to the current maximum for that level. Update the maximum if the current node's value is greater.
After processing all nodes at a given level, append the maximum value found to your results list. Make sure to reset the maximum for the next level.
Think about the constraints given in the problem statement. You need to ensure your solution can handle up to 10,000 nodes efficiently.
Finally, consider edge cases such as a tree with only one node or a tree that is skewed to one side. How would your solution handle these scenarios?

questionNotes: Return an array of the largest values for each row (0-indexed).
The tree can have between 0 and 10,000 nodes.
Ensure your solution handles empty trees correctly.
